text:
ZIA MODY: So I
actually make sure

that every woman who's
working with us obviously

goes through the
life cycles of what?

Marriage and motherhood, these
are our two crisis points

where we want to give
up the profession
or give up what we're doing.

And so I have a sort
of a checklist now.

When someone says
she's getting married,

I sit her down, say, here's
the checklist, come back to me.
Tell me I'm a genius.

Tell me I know everything,
because this is
exactly what's going to happen.

And so guidance about,
where's your infrastructure?

How are you going
to deal with it?
Are you with your mother-in-law?

Are you not with
your mother-in-law?

Do you have to fight
with your mother-in-law?

Is it a sin to be friends
with your mother-in-law?

Why don't you make
people who can help you,
your friends, your allies?
What do you get?
You get your workspace.

First child is the
worst time for a mother.

And so, we have our
little [INAUDIBLE] babies.

And I think the best
thing that you can do

is to nurture the woman through
that difficult period, which
is not much.

It's sometimes nine months, it's
sometimes six months, sometimes
a year.

It's whatever they need to
get their head comfortable.

And then, you don't
have to judge them
like every aggressive male man.

They bring a lot more to
the table in different ways.

So if the guy is doing 12
deals, if the girl at that time

is doing, not 12 deals
but eight deals, it's OK.

And if she feels
she's respected,

and if she feels you're
not doing charity to her,
she's fine.

And the men get it
because we've invested
years in this resource.

And she stayed there because
she's bright, she's committed,
she has the DNA of the firm.
She holds our letterhead high.
Why would we lose her?
It's just stupid.

So when somebody who's in
a position of leadership

says that, I guess
most people listen.
